newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy government wins Senate confidence vote.
newsitem.headline: Italy government wins Senate confidence vote.

text.p: The government won a confidence vote in the Senate (upper house) on Wednesday to convert into law a decree covering the rescue plan for the Italy's biggest southern bank, Banco di Napoli, officials said.
The government has called two more confidence votes in the Senate, where it enjoys an absolute majority, for later on Wednesday to convert into law decrees which were about to expire.
Prime Minister Romano Prodi's centre-left government coalition won the first vote with 167 votes in favour of the motion and 93 against with no abstentions.

It won similar confidence votes in the lower house last month to gain approval there for the decree on heavily-indebted Banco di Napoli, which the government wants to privatise by the end of the year.

The next two votes, called to get round opposition filibustering, concern decrees which cover development projects in Naples and socially useful labour. In Italy, laws have to be approved by both houses of parliament.

Governments have in the past sidestepped opposition by reissuing decree laws when they expired. A recent Constitutional Court ruling banned this practice, leaving Prodi with a legislative nightmare as some 20 cabinet decrees near expiry. Rome newsroom +396-6782505
